ML_AA_NAMES.AA_NAME: The Common Services Agency (more commonly known as NHS National Services Scotland) ("NSS")

ADDRESS_CONTRACTING_BODY.OFFICIALNAME: The Common Services Agency (more commonly known as NHS National Services Scotland) ("NSS")
ADDRESS_CONTRACTING_BODY.ADDRESS: Gyle Square (NSS Head Office), 1 South Gyle Crescent

TITLE.P: Joint Development with NHS NSS of an ECT Database

SHORT_DESCR.P: Scotland has a strong history in the effective use of clinical audit to drive improvements in healthcare for the people of Scotland.

This opportunity is for an exclusive development of a web based system including the ongoing use of the intellectual property for the accreditation network for Electroconvulsive Therapy [ECT], developed in Scotland and endorsed by the Royal College of Psychiatrists and Healthcare Improvement Scotland.
Scotland has a strong history in the effective use of clinical audit to drive improvements in healthcare for the people of Scotland.

This opportunity is for an exclusive development of a web based system including the ongoing use of the intellectual property for the accreditation network for Electroconvulsive Therapy [ECT], developed in Scotland and endorsed by the Royal College of Psychiatrists and Healthcare Improvement Scotland. This accreditation network has been recognised internationally for delivering demonstrable improvements in patient care and there is worldwide interest in adopting the Scottish approach.
More information on the current legacy ECT database and system, known as SEAN is available here: http://www.sean.org.uk/

The network requires a new, web-based version that is more user-friendly and efficient than the system which it will replace. The product that is developed would be managed through licence agreements and we expect that a licence will be granted to the successful company for the ongoing use of NHS intellectual property to develop and internationalise the approach. It is expected that each of the parties will bear its own costs and that the developed product will be commercially exploited by the company with resulting revenue shared with NHS Scotland.
